displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Let me see if she’s out here to sort of get a sense that I can give you some feedback that it will be in the next day or the next week to sort of say to you - Patient: And then you will let us know about chemo Doctor: Yeah, we’ve got a little bit of a window, so we probably have until early February to get started. Patient: Oh so it won’t get started before that? Doctor: No, it could start as soon as you participate in the study, we can do that, but it’s not urgent that it has to be done before Christmas or before the new year’s or before Martin Luther King - Patient: Okay. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Okay? Okay, let me see if she’s around so I can just give you a time frame um and uh thanks for bringing this in. This is very helpful. Patient: Good. Um hum. Family Member: We were happy when the results came in. Doctor: Yeah, no genes . Okay, great, good to see you. Family Member: Okay, thanks.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You know, if down the road if there are kidney problems. At least what they’ve reported so far they don’t - they don’t see it. Patient: I see. Doctor: So I would say the procedure, I normally do it on the trials, but I had this experience with the guys in Germany. What they do is they bring you there and they scan you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: With the imaging part. They see how active is your cancer. How much of the stuff is there on PSMA. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If there’s a lot there, so things look really dark, it looks like it’s taken up like crazy, then you’re a good candidate for that treatment. If it’s so-so, I don’t know what their line is, but they kind of look at it, and if it doesn’t look like the cancer is really taken off, I don’t think you’re a candidate. I would say that most people are in the first group that the cancer makes a lot of this uh so uh one of the things we’re doing here is uh looking at the scan part. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we’ve been looking at the imaging part to see how useful this is as an imaging agent but it’s also useful because if we do it here, and you’re very positive, it might suggest yes we should pursue this. Patient: Okay. Is it something than can tell you how extensive the cancer? Doctor: Yes. So the second part of that, it’s a good question. Just to, and because it’s very sensitive, it’s possible you do the scan, and they, say, oh, B__, your set of these, so many things you see here, there’s a lot more. Because they can see uh, what we’re limited by right now is as I told you these lymph nodes are enlarged. That’s pretty much all the radiologist can say right now. So if you have a normal lymph node it could be totally full of cancer. They won’t call it. They only call the ones that are bigger than normal.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um. No new allergies? Patient: No. Doctor: I’m going through your medicines. Still taking your Advair as needed? Patient: Right. Doctor: Your atorvastatin ten milligrams a day? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Co-Q-ten two hundred a day? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Lisinopril ten milligrams a day? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Multivitamin once a day? Patient: No.

Patient: Right. Family Member: Why are you taking prednisone with it? Patient: So Doctor: So the Zytiga, so the way Xtandi works is, if you think that we talked before about the, the testosterone has to get into the cell and do stuff. It has to bind in something in the cell called receptors. So the best way to think about it is a ball and glove. Xtandi kind of, if, if the ball is testosterone, Xtandi looks like an orange. And so it gets in the glove, and it blocks the ball. It can’t get in there. Uh, Zytiga works in a different way. It blocks the enzymes that the body uses to make testosterone. So there’s all these different precursors. So start with cholesterol, and it goes through about ten steps, and ends at testosterone. When you block it, there’s some hormones that build up that can affect the kidney. Patient: Hum. Doctor: And those hormones can affect how you handle water and potassium. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So what they found is if you give a little bit of prednisone, which is also kind of a hormone, it balances that out. Uh, so we just give a once-a-day low dose, and that seems to be enough to keep the potassium normal. But some people don’t like prednisone. It makes them feel weird. It makes them gain weight. It makes them eat more. Patient: Oh. (Laughter) Doctor: And so, uh, the standard dose was twice a day. We found that if we just give it once a day, it’s enough to counterbalance the thing. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, so I think either one would be fine. You know? I think choosing either one would be fine. But I think that’s what I would do next is- now, the way I do that is, the other side effect of these drugs are they’re very expensive. So what we do is, uh, we have a whole group here whose job is, if we decide we’re going to do one or the other, I will call them today, and say, “I want to put you on X.”

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You have a nurse visit. Patient: Yeah, that’s a hormone shot and a follow up. And, just before that, I’m supposed to do a three month PSA for him, so. Doctor: Okay. And then, you have another appointment with him in April. Patient: That’s correct. Doctor: Well. You gotta decide. I don’t think you need to see both of us. (Pause) Patient: Because you – Family Member: Right. Doctor: Not with Dr. S_. Patient: I’m not going to get more radi— Doctor: So, you don’t necessarily need to keep seeing him. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. Just

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 2 years (1 year but less: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 2 years (1 year but less than 2 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: So that’s where, that’s where I thought… Family Member: That’s what we just assumed it was… Doctor: Exactly. So now we’re just being super careful that you’re aware and you’re not bungee jumping and landing on your left hip and making that hurt worse. Doctor: Yeah I know. You’re not exactly outright denying me right now the bungee jumping that you’re starting to scare me or zip lining. Doctor: Terrific. Patient: I’m just thinking, I want to ask you now, Doctor: Nothing Patient: I, I’m pleased with where we’re at. Family Member: So. Doctor: I’m gonna order the x-ray. I’m gonna send you guys over there because they’re all screaming at me. They’re gonna… Patient: Order the x-ray for? Doctor: Hip.

Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: So, let me see if you want. Do you want to do it today? Patient: I mean Doctor: You can go over and do it. Patient: What? Doctor: To the treatment area. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You have an appointment there anyway. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay?

Patient: Now is it possible to get the pre and/or post treatments at a local or local - Healthcare Professional: The draw? Patient: LabCorp or Quest or something? Doctor: Yes, absolutely. Patient: Okay. ‘Cuz I don’t mind comin’ down obviously, but if I can shave a couple hours out of a day- Doctor: Yeah. If you on a Monday, went over to LabCorp, got your blood tests, awesome. Tuesday, we clear you, and if you want Wednesday or Thursday to be your chemo day, you just tell me. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, then and so, all that works from a time frame. Then, the counts, the next week which you’re getting - I don’t know if that’s for the study or - then you can get that at LabCorp. That’s gonna come to us. Uh, we don’t do much with that. That’s more if you call us, and you say, “Hey, you know, I have a fever.” We can look at those blood tests and say, “Hey, it’s low. So, you should go to the hospital.” Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now, it’s normal. You’re like everybody else. Just take your Tylenol or whatever. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, and we’ll get you a chemo teaching class.

Patient: Right. Doctor: It looks like there’s more now. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I, I don’t think we could do that radiation. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, just because of the number of them. Patient: Right. Doctor: We do, speaking of trials, we do have a trial coming up. It’s not open yet. But it’s probably going to be a trial after, uh, uh, actually, let me, let me take a step back. The other trial I didn’t tell you. We do have one other trial, uh, that involves, uh, a combination of two things. Uh, one is called, radium. And radium is a radioactive element that looks like calcium. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And the idea is we can trick the cancer, because prostate cancer is making, stimulating the bone to make new bone. (Sound Door opens) Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we give this radium that looks like calcium, so he gets put in there also, and can give radiation kind of focally. So where there’s spots on the bone, it gives radiation, but it doesn’t radiate the liver or the lung. Patient: Right. Right.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Because frequently, there are patient assistance and things like that Patient: Okay. Doctor: That we can figure out. But, we don’t know if they’ve just called you, and they haven’t told us. Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. So, if there are any hassles, any issues with the prescription, let us know. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And let us work on it. Patient: Okay. Alright. No problem. Doctor: Alright. Just, so you know. Because, this is a mighty expensive medication, and insurance does frequently give you and me the runaround Patient: Right. Doctor: Before they approve it.

Patient: Okay. But – Doctor: So, that makes it twenty-five percent. Patient: If they are negative ---- Doctor: If they’re negative, they’re negative. Patient: It’s over. Doctor: It’s over. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um okay. Patient: Are they, did E_ --- Doctor: And, then, you know, I would say your brother who has prostate cancer he probably should get tested because it’s, you know, it’s possible he has the same gene mutation, um, inherited because it is a risk factor. So, from the standpoint of your family, that’s my advice – they get tested. For you personally, what does it mean? (pause) Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We’ve also been doing clinical studies in a weird way with giving men testosterone Patient: Mm, hmm.

Family Member: Oh the pathology report. Doctor: Okay. That’s our pathology report? Family Member: Yes. Doctor: And I have actually pathology pictures that I think G____ talked to you about it? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So, I printed them out. (Papers shuffling) Patient: Mm,hmm. Doctor: - like a bread loaf. (Makes slicing sound) Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: from before and there were three spots that only had a little bit of cancer. Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: We talked about that on the phone, that’s I don’t know how to explain that.

Patient: Right. Doctor: You know, I, I say plan for three hours, but you know, if we do the Tuesday visit and clear you, then your other visits it can be the shorter end of things because they know you, they expected you, they’ve cleared you. Patient: Yeah, we’ll get into the pattern and we’ll just - Okay. Doctor: But, we’re not using, uh, uh a port. You know, we’re just going to use your regular vein. So, that would be something else that if your veins are too tough to get, uh, something like that. Patient: I’ll tell you that the phlebotomist that did it today was probably the least painful stick I’ve ever had. Doctor: Do you have any other questions? Family Member: No. Doctor: Anything else? So, uh, uh, Family Member: So you definitely did get something from the insurance company on the chemo? ‘Cuz Healthcare Professional: Yeah, the chemo, ‘cuz he’s -- Family Member: You know, what we have doesn’t show that. Healthcare Professional: No, so what you have was something that you, that has to be preauthorized. The chemo is part of the whole, um, clinical trial package, so you don’t have to have preauthorization.

Family Member 1: About three times a week. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: He asolutely loves her. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: And he was letting her eat off of him like if he took a bite of his own now. Doctor: That’s a no. Family Member 1: Yeah. Patient: I stopped doing that quite a while ago. Family Member 1: Yeah, that's what he said about a couple of weeks ago. He stopped. He's giving her separated. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: Okay, now, M_____'s pregnant, she picked up his water and drank the whole water the other day by accident. I don't know. Doctor: That's okay. Yeah, I think where when you're on chemo, you have to use universal precautions, you know. So it's always easier if you have more than one bathroom in your home. So that even if you have your own bathroom space where your towels and you can have Lysol and things. You feel comfortable. That's just his bathroom, so that you don't always constantly have to Lysol and Clorox things. Patient: Right.

Patient: Yeah and where will I get the form for the appointment? Doctor: When you head out front, along that purple wall there there’s people there. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It should be pretty clean and nobody out there now. There might be somebody there and there may not be. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, let me see if A ___ needs to see you before you go. Patient: Okay. Do you have some paperclips? That’s fine. Okay. Doctor: A _____ Needs you. Patient: Okay.
